project_metadata.paper_title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
project_metadata.research_context: This study analyses genome-wide ancient DNA data from 135 individuals from southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning approximately 5400-2400 BC, investigating the genetic contact between late Copper Age farming societies and Eneolithic steppe groups that preceded the expansion of Yamnaya pastoralists around 3300 BC.

evidence.evidence_text: Genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region were analysed
evidence.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period

evidence.evidence_text: The study period spans approximately 5400-2400 BC based on radiocarbon dating
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc

evidence.evidence_text: 135 individuals successfully sequenced from 216 attempted samples
evidence.verbatim_quote: we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals

evidence.evidence_text: Eight distinct archaeological sites sampled
evidence.verbatim_quote: 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites

evidence.evidence_text: Sample breakdown by period: Neolithic n=1, Copper Age n=95, Eneolithic n=18, Early Bronze Age n=21
evidence.verbatim_quote: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21)

evidence.evidence_text: All samples enriched for 1.24 million SNP panel
evidence.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel)

evidence.evidence_text: SNP coverage ranged from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with average coverage 0.01× to 3.4×
evidence.verbatim_quote: ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

evidence.evidence_text: Cut-off of 400,000 SNPs used for hapROH and imputation analyses
evidence.verbatim_quote: We used a cut-off of 400,000 SNPs for hapROH and imputation

evidence.evidence_text: Filter of >550,000 SNPs applied for identity-by-descent analyses
evidence.verbatim_quote: filtered for >550,000 SNPs for identity-by-descent (IBD) analyses

evidence.evidence_text: 113 new radiocarbon dates reported
evidence.verbatim_quote: We also report 113 new radiocarbon dates

evidence.evidence_text: PCA constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 populations
evidence.verbatim_quote: principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations

evidence.evidence_text: PIE039 is the earliest-dated individual and falls in expected range of SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA
evidence.verbatim_quote: The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space

evidence.evidence_text: Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N identified as most symmetrically related to PIE039
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N to be most symmetrically related to PIE039 with respect to all HG comparisons (|Z| ≤ 1)

evidence.evidence_text: Combined SEE 1 group used as single source for proximal qpAdm modelling with P=0.41
evidence.verbatim_quote: combined them into local group SEE 1, which could be used as a single source for proximal qpAdm modelling (P = 0.41)

evidence.evidence_text: SEE CA individuals from Yunatsite, Varna, Pietrele and Petko Karavelovo form tight cluster in PCA overlapping with Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE
evidence.verbatim_quote: the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster that also overlaps with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE

evidence.evidence_text: Distal qpAdm modelling confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry in SEE CA, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry
evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Table G) confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry

evidence.evidence_text: All SEE CA groups modelled as single-source from locally preceding Neolithic groups
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale

evidence.evidence_text: Outlier individual PIE060 shifted further towards WHG/EHG cluster in PCA with excess ancestry confirmed by f4 statistics (|Z|≥3)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The outlier individual PIE060 is shifted further towards the WHG/EHG cluster in PCA, suggesting an excess of this type of ancestry, which could be confirmed by f4 statistics of the form f4(SEE N, PIE060; HGs, Mbuti) ((|Z| ≥ 3)

evidence.evidence_text: PIE060 modelled as two-way mixture: ~65% SEE N and ~35% Iron Gates HG or KO1
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling with qpAdm supports a two-way model (Fig. 3d) with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%) as the best proxies

evidence.evidence_text: DATES estimated admixture for PIE060 at 16.3±13.4 generations (Z=1.213)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using DATES to determine the time of admixture between SEE N and Iron Gates HG as a local HG ancestry, we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213)

evidence.evidence_text: Y-chromosomal diversity at Pietrele: 7 different main lineages among 29 males (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a, R1b-V88)
evidence.verbatim_quote: With seven different main lineages among 29 males in Pietrele (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a and R1b-V88)

evidence.evidence_text: Y-chromosomal diversity at Varna: 6 lineages among 15 males (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1, R1b-V88)
evidence.verbatim_quote: six among 15 males in Varna (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1 and R1b-V88)

evidence.evidence_text: Y-chromosomal diversity at Yunatsite: 4 lineages among 6 males (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a)
evidence.verbatim_quote: four among six males at Yunatsite (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a)

evidence.evidence_text: READ analysis detected only 3 first-degree and 2 second-degree relationships across all SEE CA sites
evidence.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

evidence.evidence_text: No between-site IBD links up to 4th-5th degree; only two pairs shared ≥2 blocks >20cM (5th-7th degree)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree and only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

evidence.evidence_text: Higher background relatedness at Yunatsite and Varna compared to Pietrele based on IBD analysis
evidence.verbatim_quote: Integrating the normalized sum and number of shared blocks we find higher background relatedness at the intrasite level at Yunatsite and Varna compared to Pietrele

evidence.evidence_text: ROH analysis indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting large effective population sizes
evidence.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes

evidence.evidence_text: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals dated 4500-3500 BC form genetic cline between Neolithic/SEE CA and Steppe Eneolithic groups
evidence.verbatim_quote: Eneolithic individuals from Ukraine (Ukraine Eneolithic), dated from around 4500–3500 bc, associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline in PCA space (Fig. 1b) between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals from the North Caucasus and Khvalynsk in western Russia

evidence.evidence_text: Genetic cline reflects developments over ~1,000 years chronological range
evidence.verbatim_quote: The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years

evidence.evidence_text: No correlation found between PC2 position and radiocarbon dates for Ukraine Eneolithic individuals (Spearman's ρ=0.113, P=0.6656)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

evidence.evidence_text: Kartal individuals genetically heterogeneous: 5 individuals (Kartal A) form cline between Steppe Eneolithic/Steppe Maykop and Early Neolithic, 3 others (Kartal B) fall closer to Early Neolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous, with five individuals (Kartal A) forming a cline between 'Steppe Eneolithic'/'Steppe Maykop' individuals and Early Neolithic groups, while three other individuals (Kartal B) fall closer to the latter

evidence.evidence_text: Five contemporaneous Majaky individuals genetically more homogeneous than Kartal
evidence.verbatim_quote: The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous

evidence.evidence_text: Majaky and four Usatove individuals fall together in middle of 'Kartal cline'
evidence.verbatim_quote: The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous and fall together with the four individuals from the late Eneolithic Usatove type-site (USV/UBK; Supplementary Table A) in the middle of the 'Kartal cline'

evidence.evidence_text: Ukraine Eneolithic show excess affinity to all HG groups compared to Turkey_N (|Z|≥3)
evidence.verbatim_quote: First, compared to Turkey_N, Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups, as indicated by significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)

evidence.evidence_text: Compared to Steppe Eneolithic, Ukraine Eneolithic show excess affinity to Turkey_N, symmetrical relatedness to CHG and WHG
evidence.verbatim_quote: conditioning on Steppe Eneolithic (Extended Data Fig. 6b), we observe excess affinity of Ukraine Eneolithic to Turkey_N, a symmetrical relatedness to CHG and WHG, while Steppe Eneolithic groups carry more EHG/WSHG ancestry

evidence.evidence_text: Four-way admixture model (Turkey_N, EHG, CHG, WHG) supported for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using distal qpAdm modelling we find support for a four-way admixture of Turkey_N, EHG, CHG and WHG for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV

evidence.evidence_text: KTL003, KTL006, KTL008 modelled with three sources (Turkey_N+EHG+CHG)
evidence.verbatim_quote: individuals KTL003, KTL006 and KTL008 can be modelled alternatively with three sources (Turkey_N+EHG+CHG)

evidence.evidence_text: KTL_B individuals modelled with Turkey_N (~60%), CHG (~28%) and WHG (~12%) ancestry only
evidence.verbatim_quote: KTL_B individuals only with Turkey_N (around 60%), CHG (around 28%) and WHG (around 12%) ancestry

evidence.evidence_text: All Ukraine Eneolithic modelled as two-way: VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia + Steppe Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals can be modelled as a two-way model of either VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia as farmer-related ancestry source and Steppe Eneolithic as a source of mixed EHG+CHG ancestry

evidence.evidence_text: KTL001 modelled as three-way: Steppe Eneolithic (~32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (~46%), Ukraine N foragers (~22%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: KTL001 can indeed be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 46%) and Ukraine N foragers (around 22%), to the exclusion of a SEE CA source

evidence.evidence_text: Strong support for SEE CA contribution rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals (except KTL_B)
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find strong support for a genetic contribution from SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals (except KTL_B), which can be modelled as Steppe Eneolithic and VAR_CA

evidence.evidence_text: USV model with VAR_CA rejected (needs Maykop ancestry); four-way mixture model supported (P=0.93)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The same model is supported for MAJ (P = 0.05) but rejected for USV, which indicates that Maykop-associated ancestry is needed for the latter. Indeed, the competing model, with Maykop as an additional source and VAR_CA as an outgroup, results in a well-fit four-way mixture model for USV (P = 0.93)

evidence.evidence_text: IBD analysis found 4th-6th degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006, which reflects the close geographical vicinity of the two sites

evidence.evidence_text: ROH analysis shows slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV compared to CA
evidence.verbatim_quote: in comparison to the preceding CA and heterogenous KTL individuals, ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV (Extended Data Fig. 5), suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups

evidence.evidence_text: Y-chromosomal lineages from six Ukraine Eneolithic males: G2a (Neolithic legacy), three I2a1 (Ukrainian Neolithic/HG), KTL005 R1b/M343(×P297), MAJ009 R1b1/L754(×M269)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosomal evidence from the six Ukraine Eneolithic males reflects lineages from each of the contributing sources (Extended Data Fig. 3b): G2a is probably a Neolithic legacy, while three males carrying I2a1 could be attributed to the local Ukrainian Neolithic or HG groups in general. KTL005 and MAJ009 carry haplotypes R1b/M343(×P297) and R1b1/L754(×M269), respectively

evidence.evidence_text: No R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages observed in Ukraine Eneolithic males
evidence.verbatim_quote: Importantly, we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry

evidence.evidence_text: EBA individuals characterized by two contrasting clusters in PCA and different genetic affinities

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry in PCA space (Fig. 1b) and different genetic affinities in outgroup f3 statistics

evidence.evidence_text: YUN_EBA and PIE078 resemble SEE CA groups; BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA fall within 'steppe ancestry' cluster

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from YUN and individual PIE078, who date to the first half of the third millennium bc, resemble the SEE CA groups, whereas BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster, commonly associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex

evidence.evidence_text: Outlier individuals BOY019 and YUN041 fall between the two EBA clusters

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Two outlier individuals, BOY019 and YUN041, fall in the space between

evidence.evidence_text: YUN_EBA/PIE078 males carried Y-chromosome I2a (HG legacy); BOY/MAJ_EBA males carried R1b-Z2103 (Yamnaya hallmark)

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy, while the males from BOY/MAJ_EBA carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry

evidence.evidence_text: Excess HG ancestry in YUN_EBA and PIE078 confirmed by f4 statistics (|Z|≤3)

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: tested for additional attraction towards HG-related groups in YUN_EBA and PIE078 compared to their CA predecessors by using f4(CA, EBA; HGs, Mbuti) and confirmed the excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with significant negative results (|Z| ≤ 3)

evidence.evidence_text: YUN041 shows higher affinity to VAR_CA than other EBA groups

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: only the outlier individual YUN041 has a higher affinity to VAR_CA than to other EBA groups

evidence.evidence_text: PIE078 and YUN_EBA modelled with Turkey_N, CHG and WHG; MAJ_EBA, BOY_EBA, BOY019, YUN041 require EHG as additional source

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling with cornerstone populations confirms the contrasting ancestries of the two main EBA clusters. PIE078 and YUN_EBA can be modelled with Turkey_N, CHG and WHG (Fig. 3c and Supplementary Table X), whereas MAJ_EBA, BOY_EBA, BOY019 and YUN041 require EHG ancestry as an additional source

evidence.evidence_text: BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara modelled as three-way: Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, Ukraine N

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Ukraine N

evidence.evidence_text: BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara also modelled as two-way: Steppe Eneolithic + KTL001

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can also be modelled as a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic and KTL001 (who lacked SEE_CA ancestry)

evidence.evidence_text: Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya modelled as three-way (P=0.07): Steppe Eneolithic (~75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (~14%), Globular Amphora (~11%)

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%) as a western source

evidence.evidence_text: Yamnaya Caucasus modelled as two-way: ~76% Steppe Eneolithic + ~26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, confirming the findings of Lazaridis and colleagues

evidence.evidence_text: Ozera outlier modelled with 40% Steppe Eneolithic + 60% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (P=0.09)

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: This two-way mix (40% + 60%, respectively) also provides a well-fit model (P = 0.09) for the Ozera outlier individual, consistent with the position in PCA and corroborating an influence from the Caucasus

evidence.evidence_text: BOY019 modelled as ~63% USV + ~37% Steppe Eneolithic, or ~40% Ukraine Trypillia + ~60% Steppe Eneolithic

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Individual BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic

evidence.evidence_text: YUN041 modelled as ~50% YUN_EBA + ~50% BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya source

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: individual YUN041 can be modelled as around 50% local YUN_EBA ancestry and 50% of either BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya-associated source

evidence.evidence_text: All f4 statistics non-significant (|Z|≤3) for Yamnaya-associated individuals except Ukraine_Ozera_EBA_Yamnaya outlier

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: with the exception of outlier individual Ukraine_Ozera_EBA_Yamnaya, all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3) (Supplementary Table W), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar

evidence.evidence_text: Two individuals positive for Hepatitis B virus (YUN048, VAR021); VAR021 also positive for Salmonella enterica
evidence.verbatim_quote: Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV), while individual VAR021 was also positive for Salmonella enterica

evidence.evidence_text: 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth processed in total
evidence.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total

evidence.evidence_text: DNA damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA: short fragments (45-65 bp average), 6-17% deamination (UDG-half), 30-38% (non-UDG)
evidence.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA, which includes short DNA fragment lengths (45–65 bp on average) and postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules (6–17% for partial UDG treatment, 30–38% for non-UDG treatment)

evidence.evidence_text: Mitochondrial contamination estimated at 0.086% to -9.2% using ContamMix
evidence.verbatim_quote: estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix (Supplementary Table A), ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%

evidence.evidence_text: Nuclear contamination for males estimated at 0.2% to 2% using ANGSD
evidence.verbatim_quote: The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%

evidence.evidence_text: PTK001 excluded due to ~18% contamination estimate
evidence.verbatim_quote: PTK001 yielded a contamination estimate of around 18% and therefore was excluded from all further analysis

claims.claim_text: The study provides genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals spanning the critical transition period between Copper Age and Early Bronze Age in southeastern Europe
claims.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period

claims.claim_text: Genetic continuity observed between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region
claims.verbatim_quote: While we observe genetic continuity between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region

claims.claim_text: The sequencing and enrichment methods produced adequate data quality for population genetic analyses
claims.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

claims.claim_text: The sample distribution spans key archaeological periods: Neolithic, Copper Age, Eneolithic, and Early Bronze Age
claims.verbatim_quote: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21)

claims.claim_text: The new radiocarbon dates establish precise chronological control for the sampled individuals
claims.verbatim_quote: We also report 113 new radiocarbon dates

claims.claim_text: PCA using modern West Eurasian reference populations provides appropriate context for assessing ancient genetic variation
claims.verbatim_quote: principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

claims.claim_text: The earliest individual PIE039 shares genetic affinities with other SEE Neolithic individuals
claims.verbatim_quote: The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space, with whom she also shares affinities according to outgroup f3 statistics

claims.claim_text: SEE Copper Age individuals from emblematic sites form a genetically homogeneous group
claims.verbatim_quote: the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster

claims.claim_text: SEE CA populations show slight hunter-gatherer (EHG/WHG) admixture compared to Neolithic predecessors
claims.verbatim_quote: all SEE CA groups are slightly shifted towards the EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals

claims.claim_text: SEE CA ancestry derives predominantly from Anatolian Neolithic farmers with minimal hunter-gatherer contributions
claims.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry

claims.claim_text: Genetic continuity exists between Neolithic and Copper Age populations at the local scale
claims.verbatim_quote: we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale

claims.claim_text: Individual PIE060 represents recent admixture between local Neolithic populations and hunter-gatherers
claims.verbatim_quote: The outlier individual PIE060 is shifted further towards the WHG/EHG cluster in PCA, suggesting an excess of this type of ancestry

claims.claim_text: Y-chromosomal diversity during SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe
claims.verbatim_quote: the Y-chromosomal diversity during the SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe

claims.claim_text: Close genetic relatedness between SEE CA sites was limited, with only a few first- and second-degree relationships detected
claims.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

claims.claim_text: No evidence for close genetic links between contemporaneous CA sites up to the 4th-5th degree
claims.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree

claims.claim_text: Differences in background relatedness between sites reflect site structure and duration of use
claims.verbatim_quote: we find higher background relatedness at the intrasite level at Yunatsite and Varna compared to Pietrele, which can be explained by the structure of the sites (a destruction horizon of households and a burial ground with shorter use, respectively, versus tell and settlement burials spanning 350–400 years)

claims.claim_text: Low ROH levels indicate relatively large effective population sizes during the Copper Age, consistent with earlier farming societies
claims.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes, consistent with previous observation across early farming societies

claims.claim_text: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals represent admixture between CA farmer-related groups and Eneolithic steppe groups
claims.verbatim_quote: This indicates possible admixture between CA farmer-related groups and Eneolithic steppe groups, as in line with cultural interactions described in the archaeological record

claims.claim_text: The observed genetic cline in Ukraine Eneolithic developed over approximately 1,000 years
claims.verbatim_quote: The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years

claims.claim_text: The genetic cline is not simply a temporal gradient but reflects complex admixture processes
claims.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

claims.claim_text: The Kartal site shows exceptional genetic heterogeneity, representing the transformative dynamics of the 4th millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous

claims.claim_text: Majaky and Usatove groups show more homogeneous ancestry, indicating completed assimilation processes
claims.verbatim_quote: The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous and fall together with the four individuals from the late Eneolithic Usatove type-site

claims.claim_text: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals have hunter-gatherer ancestry not fully explained by either farmer or steppe sources
claims.verbatim_quote: compared to Turkey_N, Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups, as indicated by significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)

claims.claim_text: Ukraine Eneolithic ancestry derives from farmer-related sources with additional steppe-related (EHG/WSHG) contributions
claims.verbatim_quote: we observe excess affinity of Ukraine Eneolithic to Turkey_N, a symmetrical relatedness to CHG and WHG, while Steppe Eneolithic groups carry more EHG/WSHG ancestry

claims.claim_text: Kartal B individuals lack EHG ancestry, distinguishing them from other Ukraine Eneolithic individuals
claims.verbatim_quote: KTL_B individuals only with Turkey_N (around 60%), CHG (around 28%) and WHG (around 12%) ancestry

claims.claim_text: Proximal modelling shows Ukraine Eneolithic ancestry derives from local farmer and steppe Eneolithic sources
claims.verbatim_quote: all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals can be modelled as a two-way model of either VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia as farmer-related ancestry source and Steppe Eneolithic as a source of mixed EHG+CHG ancestry

claims.claim_text: KTL001 represents a distinct admixture pattern without SEE CA contribution, involving Caucasus-related ancestry
claims.verbatim_quote: KTL001 can indeed be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 46%) and Ukraine N foragers (around 22%), to the exclusion of a SEE CA source

claims.claim_text: Majaky and Usatove populations have distinct admixture history involving local CA, Steppe Eneolithic, and Caucasus contributions
claims.verbatim_quote: MAJ and USV can be modelled as VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia (around 50%), Steppe Eneolithic (around 35%) and Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 15%) as minor third component

claims.claim_text: Most Kartal individuals received genetic contribution from SEE CA farmers rather than Caucasus groups
claims.verbatim_quote: we find strong support for a genetic contribution from SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals

claims.claim_text: Usatove individuals require Maykop-associated ancestry, indicating different admixture history from Kartal
claims.verbatim_quote: rejected for USV, which indicates that Maykop-associated ancestry is needed for the latter

claims.claim_text: Majaky and Usatove populations share close genetic relationships reflecting geographic proximity
claims.verbatim_quote: we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006, which reflects the close geographical vicinity of the two sites

claims.claim_text: Usatove-associated groups had smaller effective population sizes than preceding CA populations
claims.verbatim_quote: ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV, suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups

claims.claim_text: Y-chromosomal lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic males reflect contributions from each ancestral source
claims.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosomal evidence from the six Ukraine Eneolithic males reflects lineages from each of the contributing sources

claims.claim_text: Absence of R1b-Z2103 lineages indicates Ukraine Eneolithic males predate the later steppe expansion
claims.verbatim_quote: we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry

claims.claim_text: Early Bronze Age individuals show two contrasting genetic ancestry patterns

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry in PCA space

claims.claim_text: Some EBA individuals at tell sites maintained CA ancestry without steppe admixture

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: Individuals from YUN and individual PIE078, who date to the first half of the third millennium bc, resemble the SEE CA groups

claims.claim_text: Two outlier individuals (BOY019, YUN041) represent intermediate ancestry between local and incoming populations

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: Two outlier individuals, BOY019 and YUN041, fall in the space between

claims.claim_text: Y-chromosome lineages distinguish local EBA populations (I2a) from incoming Yamnaya groups (R1b-Z2103)

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy, while the males from BOY/MAJ_EBA carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry

claims.claim_text: EBA individuals at Yunatsite and Pietrele show a resurgence of hunter-gatherer ancestry

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: confirmed the excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with significant negative results

claims.claim_text: YUN041 represents admixture between local EBA population and incoming Yamnaya groups

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: only the outlier individual YUN041 has a higher affinity to VAR_CA than to other EBA groups

claims.claim_text: Distal modelling confirms two distinct EBA clusters with different ancestral compositions

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling with cornerstone populations confirms the contrasting ancestries of the two main EBA clusters

claims.claim_text: Yamnaya ancestry formation involved similar tripartite sources as earlier Ukraine Eneolithic

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: We note that the same three sources contributed to the preceding Ukraine Eneolithic individuals from USV and MAJ (in addition to SEE CA ancestry), which suggests that similar processes had led to the tripartite ancestry formation in the steppe zone during the fourth millennium bc

claims.claim_text: Some Yamnaya-associated groups can be modelled as deriving from earlier Ukraine Eneolithic populations

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can also be modelled as a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic and KTL001

claims.claim_text: Ukraine Yamnaya shows potential western (Globular Amphora) contributions in addition to steppe ancestry

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%)

claims.claim_text: Ukraine Eneolithic groups may have directly contributed to steppe pastoralists in the third millennium BC

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 65%) and USV (around 35%) (Supplementary Table Y), which suggests a possible direct contribution of Ukraine Eneolithic groups to steppe pastoralists in the third millennium bc

claims.claim_text: Yamnaya Caucasus has distinct ancestry reflecting southern steppe geographic position

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop

claims.claim_text: The Ozera outlier individual corroborates Caucasus influence on some steppe populations

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: This two-way mix (40% + 60%, respectively) also provides a well-fit model (P = 0.09) for the Ozera outlier individual, consistent with the position in PCA and corroborating an influence from the Caucasus

claims.claim_text: BOY019 represents interaction between neighbouring groups in the western contact zone

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic, suggesting interaction between these two neighbouring groups in the western contact zone

claims.claim_text: All Yamnaya-associated individuals are genetically highly similar despite geographic spread

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar

claims.claim_text: Systematic pathogen screening found no evidence for plague or other pathogens in most CA individuals
claims.verbatim_quote: Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals

claims.claim_text: Ancient DNA damage patterns and low contamination estimates confirm authenticity of the genomic data
claims.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA

claims.claim_text: Quality control procedures excluded highly contaminated samples from analysis
claims.verbatim_quote: PTK001 yielded a contamination estimate of around 18% and therefore was excluded from all further analysis

claims.claim_text: The genetic homogeneity of SEE CA populations matches the cultural homogeneity of the archaeological record
claims.verbatim_quote: The genetic homogeneity observed in and across the four CA sites (PIE, YUN, PTK and VAR) of the fifth millennium bc matches the cultural homogeneity of the archaeological records

claims.claim_text: Genetic analyses would be blind to internal conflicts causing replacement of one CA group by another
claims.verbatim_quote: given the near-identical genetic ancestry profiles of SEE CA groups, we caution that genetic analyses would be blind to internal conflicts, causing the replacement of one CA group by another

claims.claim_text: Early contact and admixture between CA farming groups and Eneolithic steppe groups began around 4500 BC
claims.verbatim_quote: A principal finding from our study indicates early contact and admixture between CA farming groups from SEE and Eneolithic groups from the steppe zone in today's southern Ukraine, possibly starting in the middle of the fifth millennium bc

claims.claim_text: Livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through interaction zones, leading to fully developed pastoralism by end of 4th millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: We argue that livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through these zones of interaction, which then led to the establishment of fully developed pastoralism in the steppe by the end of the fourth millennium bc

claims.claim_text: Early Eneolithic admixture did not affect the SEE hinterland; EBA individuals from Yunatsite and Pietrele show no steppe ancestry
claims.verbatim_quote: The early admixture during the Eneolithic presented in this study appears to be local to the northwestern Black Sea region of the fourth millennium bc and did not affect the hinterland in SEE. In fact, EBA individuals from the fourth and third millennia bc from YUN and PIE do not show traces of steppe-like ancestry

claims.claim_text: EBA resurgence of hunter-gatherer ancestry indicates presence of remnant HG groups in non-farmed regions
claims.verbatim_quote: a resurgence of HG ancestry observed widely in Europe during the fourth millennium bc. This indicates the presence of remnant HG groups in various non-farmed regions, for example, highlands and uplands or densely forested zones and wetlands

claims.claim_text: Interaction between local and incoming groups in SEE did not result in visible conflicts or near-complete genetic turnover as in Britain
claims.verbatim_quote: The interaction between local and incoming groups in SEE did not result in archaeologically visible conflicts or a near-complete autosomal genetic turnover as observed in Britain or a replacement of the Y-chromosome lineages in the Iberian Peninsula

claims.claim_text: The transfer of innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders was integral to formation of pastoralist groups around 3300 BC
claims.verbatim_quote: We propose that the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders from different ecogeographic zones during this early contact was integral to the formation, rise and expansion of pastoralist groups around 3300 bc

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Genetic admixture patterns accurately reflect historical population interactions and migrations
trigger_text: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals
indicating genetic and cultural contact over a period of around 1,000 years earlier than anticipated
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study equates genetic admixture signals with historical contact and interaction. This assumes genetic data reliably records population-level interactions.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Principal Component Analysis positions meaningfully represent genetic relationships and ancestry proportions
trigger_text: form a genetic cline in PCA space
falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study uses PCA position as primary evidence for ancestry interpretation. This assumes PCA adequately captures genetic structure relevant to population history.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: qpAdm modelling results with P>0.05 represent biologically meaningful ancestry proportions
trigger_text: proximal qpAdm modelling (P = 0.41)
well-fit model (P = 0.93)
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study interprets qpAdm P-values as validation of ancestry models. This assumes the statistical threshold appropriately distinguishes true ancestry scenarios from chance fits.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Ancient DNA preservation is sufficiently representative to allow population-level inferences
trigger_text: we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals
All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study draws population-level conclusions from individuals who happened to preserve DNA. This assumes no systematic bias in which individuals' DNA survived.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Archaeological cultural designations correspond to biologically meaningful population units
trigger_text: associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures
associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study groups individuals by archaeological culture and expects genetic coherence. This assumes archaeological cultures represent populations that were genetically distinguishable.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: The reference populations used for ancestry modelling adequately represent true ancestral source populations
trigger_text: Turkey_N, EHG, CHG and WHG
Steppe Eneolithic as a source of mixed EHG+CHG ancestry
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study uses modern reference populations and limited ancient samples as proxies for ancestral groups. This assumes these proxies adequately capture the genetic diversity of true source populations.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Y-chromosome haplogroup distributions reflect male-mediated population history distinct from autosomal ancestry
trigger_text: the Y-chromosomal diversity during the SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe
R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study interprets Y-chromosome lineages as indicators of male-mediated migration patterns. This assumes uniparental markers reliably indicate sex-biased population processes.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Genetic contact implies social interaction involving technology transfer and cultural exchange
trigger_text: indicating genetic and cultural contact
We argue that livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through these zones of interaction
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study moves from genetic admixture to claims about technology transfer. This bridges genetic evidence to social/economic conclusions not directly observable in DNA.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: Radiocarbon dates accurately reflect individual chronology despite potential reservoir effects
trigger_text: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect
an offset of around 500 years would still date most of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to the fourth millennium bc
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study acknowledges potential dating issues but proceeds with chronological interpretations. This assumes reservoir effects are bounded and do not fundamentally alter conclusions.

implicit_arguments.implicit_text: The sampled sites are representative of broader regional population dynamics
trigger_text: from eight distinct sites
individuals from well-known, contemporaneous CA settlements (Pietrele and Yunatsite) and outstanding burial sites (Varna)
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The study generalises from eight sites to regional conclusions. This assumes the famous/well-excavated sites sampled represent broader population patterns.

research_designs.description: Strategic comparison of ancient DNA from 8 archaeological sites across southeastern Europe and northwestern Black Sea region to trace genetic changes and population interactions during critical transition period (5400-2400 BC)
research_designs.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period
research_designs.rationale: To understand genetic changes during the transition from late farming to pastoralist societies by sampling multiple sites representing different cultural complexes

research_designs.description: Systematic sampling across approximately 3000 years (5400-2400 BC) to track temporal genetic changes through Neolithic, Copper Age, Eneolithic, and Early Bronze Age periods
research_designs.verbatim_quote: we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21)
research_designs.rationale: To establish chronological control and track genetic continuity or change across archaeological periods

research_designs.description: Targeted sampling of the interaction zone between late Copper Age farming groups and steppe-associated groups to characterize admixture patterns
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This northwestern Black Sea region represents an interaction zone between late CA farming-associated groups and those of the adjacent steppe region with different ecogeographic conditions
research_designs.rationale: To capture genetic evidence of contact and admixture between farming and pastoral populations in the hypothesised contact zone

research_designs.description: Application of established population genetics methods (PCA, f-statistics, qpAdm) to characterise ancestry components and admixture patterns in ancient populations
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To assess the genetic ancestry and variation of the newly typed individuals we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected
research_designs.rationale: Standard analytical framework for ancient DNA population genetics enabling comparison with published datasets

methods.description: Extraction of ancient DNA from skeletal remains (petrous bones and teeth) in dedicated clean room facilities
methods.verbatim_quote: Ancient DNA work was carried out in dedicated clean room facilities of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology (MPI-EVA), Leipzig and Jena, Germany. We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total.

methods.description: Construction of sequencing libraries using partial UDG treatment for damage assessment and single-stranded protocols for low-yield samples
methods.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment. For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries

methods.description: In-solution capture targeting 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms for genome-wide analysis
methods.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

methods.description: PCA projection of ancient individuals onto modern West Eurasian genetic variation to visualise ancestry patterns
methods.verbatim_quote: principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

methods.description: Quantitative ancestry modelling using qpAdm to estimate proportions of different ancestral populations
methods.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling and ancestry proportion estimation on the 1,240,000 SNP dataset was performed using qpAdm in ADMIXTOOLS (v.5.1)

methods.description: Computation of outgroup f3 and f4 statistics to assess genetic affinities and test for admixture
methods.verbatim_quote: Outgroup f3 statistics were calculated using qp3Pop to obtain the genetic relatedness of a target population to a set of ancient Eurasian populations since the divergence from an African outgroup. The f4 and f3 statistics were calculated using qpDstat and the f4mode: YES function.

methods.description: Detection of shared IBD segments to infer close and distant genetic relationships between individuals
methods.verbatim_quote: To specifically test for links between the contemporaneous SEE CA sites and for more distant genetic relatedness we explored signals of IBD sharing between individuals in and between all sites

methods.description: Analysis of ROH patterns to assess parental relatedness and effective population sizes
methods.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes

methods.description: Estimation of biological relatedness between individuals using READ software
methods.verbatim_quote: Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings.

methods.description: Assignment of Y-chromosomal haplogroups using manual assignment method and targeted YMCA capture
methods.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosome haplogroups for all male individuals were assigned using the manual assignment method of Y-haplogroup calling

methods.description: Assignment of mitochondrial DNA haplogroups using HaploGrep2
methods.verbatim_quote: HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup

methods.description: AMS radiocarbon dating of skeletal remains for chronological control
methods.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany

methods.description: Assessment of DNA damage patterns and contamination levels to authenticate ancient DNA
methods.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA, which includes short DNA fragment lengths (45–65 bp on average) and postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules

methods.description: Estimation of admixture timing using decay of ancestry covariance
methods.verbatim_quote: The software DATES (v.753) was used to estimate the time of the admixture events of ancient populations under the assumption that gene flow occurred as a single event and that the generation time is 28 years

methods.description: Imputation of missing genotypes using GLIMPSE software with 1000 Genomes reference panel
methods.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters

methods.description: Systematic screening of shotgun data for ancient pathogen DNA
methods.verbatim_quote: Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2)

methods.description: Processing of raw sequencing data including read mapping, duplicate removal, and genotype calling
methods.verbatim_quote: EAGER v.1.92.56 was used to process raw ancient DNA sequence data. Raw reads were trimmed for Illumina adaptor sequences using AdapterRemoval v.2.3.0. Subsequently, reads were mapped to the human reference genome hs37d5 using BWA v.0.7.12 and duplicates were removed using DeDup v.0.12.1

methods.description: Criteria for selecting which archaeological samples to attempt DNA extraction from
methods.trigger_text: we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals
expected_information_missing: Criteria for initial sample selection from larger skeletal collections
methods.notes: 81 samples (37.5%) failed to yield sufficient data, but selection criteria for attempting 216 samples not specified

methods.description: Process for selecting and curating reference populations for comparative analyses
methods.trigger_text: we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations
expected_information_missing: Quality control applied to reference data
methods.notes: Standard reference panel from Human Origins array but selection/curation not detailed in this paper

protocols.description: Minimally invasive sampling of petrous bone portion of temporal bone for ancient DNA extraction
protocols.verbatim_quote: Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method

protocols.description: Sampling teeth by separating crown from root and drilling out inner pulp chamber
protocols.verbatim_quote: for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out

protocols.description: Modified Dabney protocol for DNA extraction from skeletal remains
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64

parameters.protocol_reference: Dabney et al. 2013, Velsko et al. 2020

protocols.description: Double-stranded library construction with partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase treatment to preserve damage signal while reducing sequencing errors
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment

protocols.description: Automated single-stranded library preparation for samples with insufficient DNA yield
protocols.verbatim_quote: For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries

protocols.description: Application of unique pairs of indices to all libraries for multiplexed sequencing
protocols.verbatim_quote: All libraries were double-indexed with a unique pair of indices

protocols.description: Initial shotgun sequencing to assess human DNA content and damage profiles
protocols.verbatim_quote: all indexed libraries were screened by means of shotgun sequencing of 5 million reads on an Illumina HiSeq4000 or NextSeq500 sequencing platform using a single end (1 × 75 base pair (bp) reads) kit, followed by an assessment of human DNA content and DNA damage profiles

protocols.description: In-solution capture enrichment targeting 1.24 million SNPs for genome-wide analysis
protocols.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture (1,240,000 SNP capture)

protocols.description: Additional mitochondrial DNA capture for individuals with insufficient by-catch reads
protocols.verbatim_quote: An additional mitochondrial capture was performed for individuals for which enough reads could not be obtained as by-catch of the 1,240,000 capture, resulting in an average coverage of 64×

protocols.description: In-house Y-chromosome capture assay targeting non-recombining region
protocols.verbatim_quote: For selected male individuals we also performed an inhouse capture assay for the Y chromosome (YMCA) which targets around 10.445 kB on the non-combining region of the Y chromosome and which resulted in a mean coverage of 0.08×

protocols.description: Removal of Illumina adapter sequences from raw reads
protocols.verbatim_quote: Raw reads were trimmed for Illumina adaptor sequences using AdapterRemoval v.2.3.0

protocols.description: Alignment of reads to human reference genome hs37d5
protocols.verbatim_quote: reads were mapped to the human reference genome hs37d5 using BWA v.0.7.12 and duplicates were removed using DeDup v.0.12.1

protocols.description: Assessment of postmortem DNA damage patterns using mapDamage
protocols.verbatim_quote: To analyse characteristic DNA damage in the form of G to A and C to T substitutions, mapDamage v.2.0.9 was used

protocols.description: Removal of 2bp from read ends to minimise effect of postmortem damage on genotyping
protocols.verbatim_quote: The effect of postmortem DNA damage on genotyping was minimized by removing 2 bp from the 3′ and 5′ ends of reads from double-stranded UDG-half-treated libraries (n = 131) using the trimbam function

protocols.description: Pseudohaploid genotype calling by random allele selection at each position
protocols.verbatim_quote: The resulting filtered bam files were genotyped with pileupCaller v.1.4.0.2 by randomly calling one allele per position considering the human genome as a pseudohaploid genome (–randomHaploid)

protocols.description: Estimation of mitochondrial and nuclear contamination levels
protocols.verbatim_quote: We merged Shotgun, 1,240,000 and mitochondrial capture data for each individual, mapped this against the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence for the complete human mitochondrial genome (NC 012920.1) and estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix, ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%. The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%.

protocols.description: Estimation of kinship using READ software with default parameters
protocols.verbatim_quote: Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings. Background relatedness was estimated using the median value, across all sites per temporal group

protocols.description: Assignment of mitochondrial and Y-chromosomal haplogroups
protocols.verbatim_quote: Trimmed Shotgun, 1,240,000 and mitochondrial capture reads were aligned to the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence for the complete human mitochondrial genome (NC 012920.1) and a consensus sequence for each individual was retrieved using Geneious v.2019.2.3. HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup

protocols.description: Projection of ancient individuals onto PCA of modern West Eurasian populations
protocols.verbatim_quote: Data on the HO panel (around 600,000 SNPs) were used for PCA using the program 'smartpca' v.16000 (EIGENSOFT). Principal components were computed for 1,253 present-day western Eurasians from 77 different populations on which ancient individuals were projected, using the options 'lsqproject: YES' and 'shrinkmode: YES'. Individuals with fewer than 30,000 SNPs on the HO-dataset covered were excluded from the PCA.

protocols.description: Ancestry proportion estimation using qpAdm with specified outgroup sets
protocols.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling and ancestry proportion estimation on the 1,240,000 SNP dataset was performed using qpAdm in ADMIXTOOLS (v.5.1). The following groups were used as a basic set of outgroups for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG.SG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG

protocols.description: Computation of f3 and f4 statistics using ADMIXTOOLS
protocols.verbatim_quote: Outgroup f3 statistics were calculated using qp3Pop to obtain the genetic relatedness of a target population to a set of ancient Eurasian populations since the divergence from an African outgroup. The f4 and f3 statistics were calculated using qpDstat and the f4mode: YES function. Standard errors were computed with the default block jackknife approach

protocols.description: Imputation of low-coverage ancient genomes using GLIMPSE with 1000 Genomes reference
protocols.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters. Briefly, bam files were trimmed 2 bp to remove ancient DNA damage. We then determined genotype likelihoods from trimmed bam files using bcftools with the 1,000G panel (The 1,000 Genomes Project consortium) as a reference. We used GLIMPSE_impute on genomic chunks of 2,000,000 bp with the buffer size of 200,000 bp to perform imputation.

protocols.description: Detection of shared IBD segments using ancIBD on imputed data
protocols.verbatim_quote: IBD sharing analysis was done using ancIBD (v.0.4) on individuals with more than 600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities > 0.99 after imputation with GLIMPSE. We used HapBLOCK to perform the IBD sharing estimation... only shared blocks of more than 220 SNPs per centimorgan and shared blocks of more than 5 cM were kept for data quality purposes

protocols.description: Detection of runs of homozygosity using hapROH
protocols.verbatim_quote: The software package HapROH (v.0.64) was used to analyse ROH on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data. Only samples with more than 400,000 SNPs were included in the analysis to prevent potential false positives

protocols.description: AMS radiocarbon dating with IntCal20 calibration
protocols.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany. All samples were calibrated on the basis of the IntCal20 database and using OxCal v.4.4.2

protocols.description: Estimation of admixture timing using DATES software
protocols.verbatim_quote: The software DATES (v.753) was used to estimate the time of the admixture events of ancient populations under the assumption that gene flow occurred as a single event and that the generation time is 28 years. DATES measures the decay of ancestry covariance to infer the admixture time and estimates the variance of this admixture using a jackknife approach. The following parameters were used for every run: binsize 0.001; maxdis 1; qbin 10; lovalfit 0.45

protocols.description: Screening for ancient pathogen DNA using HOPS pipeline
protocols.verbatim_quote: Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2). First, adaptor-clipped reads were mapped to a custom-made RefSeq database using MALT v.0.4.0 in BlastN mode and with semiglobal alignment type and default pipeline settings. The used database included all available complete bacterial and viral genomes as of 2017 in addition to selected eukaryotic pathogen genomes and the human reference sequence GRCh38

protocols.description: Estimation of genetic sex from relative coverage on X, Y, and autosomal chromosomes
protocols.verbatim_quote: We estimated the genetic sex by calculating the coverage on the X, Y and the autosomal chromosomes, for which the X and Y coverage is normalized by the autosomal coverage and the relative length of each sex chromosome

protocols.description: Contamination prevention protocols used in dedicated ancient DNA facilities
protocols.trigger_text: Ancient DNA work was carried out in dedicated clean room facilities of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology
protocols.notes: MPI-EVA has published clean room protocols elsewhere; standard for ancient DNA but not detailed here

protocols.description: Decision process for determining when to retry failed samples vs. abandon
protocols.trigger_text: For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries
expected_information_missing: Specific threshold values for 'did not meet threshold'
protocols.notes: Only states that single-stranded libraries were used for low-yield samples, not the complete decision protocol

protocols.description: Process for assigning individuals to archaeological cultures and time periods
expected_information_missing: How radiocarbon dates inform period assignment
Role of archaeological context vs. direct dating
protocols.notes: Period assignments stated but methodology for assignment not detailed

protocols.description: Criteria for identifying and treating genetic outlier individuals
protocols.trigger_text: The outlier individual PIE060 is shifted further towards the WHG/EHG cluster in PCA
protocols.notes: Multiple outliers mentioned (PIE060, BOY019, YUN041) but formal outlier definition not specified

protocols.description: Criteria for selecting among competing qpAdm models and interpreting P-values
protocols.trigger_text: Indicates non-supported/rejected/failed models when applying a P value cut-off of less than 0.05
expected_information_missing: Criteria for preferring simpler vs. complex models
How to handle multiple supported models
Role of archaeological plausibility in model selection
protocols.notes: P<0.05 threshold stated but complete model selection logic not detailed

protocols.description: Process for handling closely related individuals in population analyses
protocols.trigger_text: From pairs of first-degree relatives, the individual with lower number of SNPs on the 1,240,000 target region was excluded from downstream analysis
protocols.notes: First-degree exclusion stated but handling of other degrees less clear

protocols.description: Assessment of potential freshwater reservoir effects on radiocarbon dates
protocols.trigger_text: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates
expected_information_missing: Isotopic criteria for identifying affected individuals
protocols.notes: Potential reservoir effect acknowledged but assessment methodology not detailed

protocols.description: Filtering of C>T and G>A transitions from non-UDG Y-chromosome data
protocols.trigger_text: In the case of non-UDG treated sequence, YMCA data were filtered to exclude C to T and G to A transitions on the forward and reverse strands, respectively
protocols.notes: Filtering mentioned but implementation details not provided

protocols.description: Process for merging data from identical individuals sampled multiple times
protocols.trigger_text: Three individuals from PIE were identified as identical and were therefore merged for downstream analysis. Two pairs of the newly published samples from YUN CA had to be merged as they were revealed to be the same individuals
protocols.notes: Merging of identical individuals mentioned but methodology not detailed

protocols.description: Process for integrating newly generated data with published ancient DNA datasets
protocols.trigger_text: The new genotype data were restricted to two sets of reference panels, the Affymetrix Axiom Genome-wide Human Origins1 array (HO; 593,124 autosomal SNPs) and the 1,240,000 panel
protocols.notes: AADR v44.3 mentioned as source but integration procedures not detailed

protocols.description: Criteria for authenticating detected pathogen DNA as ancient
protocols.trigger_text: The results were filtered with a predefined list of pathogens of interest and possible candidates authenticated on the basis of edit distance distribution, ancient DNA damage pattern and read distribution along the reference genome
protocols.notes: Authentication criteria mentioned in general terms but specific thresholds not provided

data_dois.description: DNA sequences reported in this paper

protocol_dois.description: Minimally-invasive sampling of pars petrosa for ancient DNA extraction V.2
Tooth sampling from the inner pulp chamber for ancient DNA Extraction V.2
Ancient DNA extraction from skeletal material
Half-UDG treated double-stranded ancient DNA library preparation V.1
Illumina double-stranded DNA dual indexing for ancient DNA V.2

persistent_identifiers.notes: No author ORCIDs listed in paper. Multiple protocols.io DOIs referenced for lab procedures.

funding.acknowledgement_text: This research was funded by the Max Planck Society, the European Research Council under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement nos 771234-PALEoRIDER, W.H.; 834616-ARCHCAUCASUS, S.H.; and 678901-FoodTransforms, P.W.S.) and the ERA.Net RUS Plus initiative (S&T-277-BIOARCCAUCASUS, S.H.).

data_availability.statement: The DNA sequences reported in this paper have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB62503.
data_availability.processed_data_description: Published genotype data compiled in Allen Ancient DNA Resource (AADR) v44.3
data_availability.supplementary_tables_description: Supplementary Tables A-Y containing sample information, statistics, and analysis results

code_availability.analysis_pipelines_description: Analysis performed using published software with versions specified: EAGER v1.92.56, ADMIXTOOLS v5.1, smartpca v16000, GLIMPSE v1.0.1, ancIBD v0.4, hapROH v0.64, DATES v753, HOPS v0.2
code_availability.notes: No custom code repository provided. Standard archaeogenetics pipelines with well-documented software used.

author_contributions.statement: W.H., S.H., P.W.S. and J.K. designed the study. R.K., G.G.-R., C.S., M.A.S., G.U.N., A. Chohadzhiev, A.S., K.P., S.R., M.L., I.M., B.G., K. Boyadzhiev, Y.B., K. Beutler and I.B. provided materials and resources. S.P. performed laboratory experiments. S.P., A.B.R., G.G.-R., C.S., G.U.N. and A. Childebayeva analysed the data. W.H., I.M., S.H., P.W.S., Y.B. and K. Boyadzhiev assisted with data interpretation. S.P., S.H., P.W.S., I.M., A.B.R. and W.H. wrote the manuscript with contributions from all co-authors.

conflicts_of_interest.statement: The authors declare no competing interests.

ethics_approval.ethics_statement: No ethics oversight was required. The archaeological and anthropological researchers included as coauthors of this study were granted permissions to sample skeletal elements for the purpose of ancient DNA analyses.
ethics_approval.notes: Ancient DNA study - no living participants. Permissions granted by archaeological collaborators and museum curators.

permits_and_authorizations.statement: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study.
permits_listed: Regional Museum of History - Veliko Tarnovo (Germany)
Institute for Geography of Goethe University - Frankfurt/Main (Germany)
Varna Regional Museum of History - Varna (Bulgaria)
National Institute of Archaeology with Museum - Sofia (Bulgaria)
permits_and_authorizations.notes: Permissions from excavators and museum curators listed as co-authors

supplementary_materials.description: Supplementary Information and Supplementary Tables A-Y available at Nature website

references_completeness.notes: Comprehensive reference list including method papers, software citations, and archaeological context

findable.notes: DOI present, data deposited in ENA with accession number, metadata in supplementary tables. Minor deduction for no author ORCIDs.

accessible.notes: Open access paper, raw sequence data publicly accessible in ENA, supplementary materials available

interoperable.notes: Data in standard BAM format, uses established 1240K SNP panel compatible with AADR, standard bioinformatics formats. Minor deduction for processed genotype data format not explicitly specified.

reusable.notes: Data well-documented with metadata, protocols referenced via protocols.io DOIs, software versions specified. Minor deduction for no analysis code repository.

fair_assessment.assessment_notes: Strong FAIR compliance for archaeogenetics publication. Primary data accessible, methods well-documented, integrated with AADR community resource. Main gap is absence of analysis code repository.

extraction_metadata.notes: Infrastructure extraction from Nature archaeogenetics paper with strong data sharing practices

known_limitations: Complex statistical methods require reference to supplementary materials
extraction_notes.section_extracted: Pass 10 complete - Final credibility report: GOOD (aggregate: 77/100, confidence: HIGH). Clusters: C1=strong, C2=strong, C3=adequate.

primary_approach.description: Quantitative analysis of ancient DNA data using population genetics methods

research_paradigm.description: Assumes genetic data reveals objective population histories that existed independently of the researchers
research_paradigm.notes: Standard population genetics paradigm with explicit statistical inference framework

data_type.description: Primary data are genome-wide SNP genotypes from ancient skeletal remains; supported by radiocarbon dates and archaeological context

analytical_framework.notes: Uses established ADMIXTOOLS framework with P-value threshold of 0.05

sample_characteristics.spatial_range: Southeastern Europe and northwestern Black Sea region
sample_characteristics.notes: 135 successfully sequenced individuals from 216 attempted; samples from 8 archaeological sites

claim_types_distribution.notes: Majority of claims are empirical (genetic patterns) or interpretive (population history)

reproducibility_potential.technical_notes: Raw sequence data deposited in ENA; methods use standard published software with versions specified
reproducibility_potential.analytical_notes: Statistical analyses use established ADMIXTOOLS package; parameters specified in methods
reproducibility_potential.inferential_notes: Population history interpretations depend on choice of reference populations and modelling assumptions
reproducibility_potential.overall_assessment: Strong potential for technical/analytical reproducibility; interpretive conclusions more dependent on analytical choices

appropriate_assessment_framework.notes: Standard scientific assessment framework appropriate; focus on methodological transparency and reproducibility

field_standards.quality_thresholds: SNP coverage >400K for ROH, >550K for IBD

discipline_context.notes: Paper follows established archaeogenetics community standards for data sharing and analysis

extraction_completeness.notes: All extraction passes completed successfully with PASS validation status

sourcing_quality.notes: 100% sourcing completeness achieved - all items have verbatim quotes or trigger text

cross_reference_integrity.notes: All cross-references validated and bidirectional mappings reconciled

extraction_coverage.notes: Extraction count (199 items) within expected range for comprehensive archaeogenetics study

rationalization_quality.notes: Low rationalization percentages appropriate for well-differentiated archaeogenetics methodology

implicit_content_capture.notes: 21% implicit RDMAP indicates moderate methodological transparency, consistent with Nature format constraints

recommendations: Strong extraction quality supports reliable credibility assessment
High FAIR score (35/40) indicates good reproducibility infrastructure
Well-documented archaeogenetics methodology enables method assessment

key_findings: Hypotheses explicitly stated with clear temporal/spatial boundaries
Code repository absent - main transparency gap
Strong theoretical grounding in established archaeogenetics framework
Multiple methods (PCA, qpAdm, f-statistics, IBD, ROH) provide convergent evidence
Raw data available in ENA with open access
Standard tools (ADMIXTOOLS, EAGER) with versions specified
Reproduction feasible with moderate preparatory work

strengths: Raw sequence data openly available in ENA (PRJEB62503)
Multiple complementary methods provide convergent evidence
Claims clearly bounded by geography, chronology, and sampled populations
FAIR score 35/40 indicates strong data sharing practices
concerns: No code repository for analysis scripts

credibility_report.bottom_line: A methodologically sound archaeogenetics study meeting current disciplinary standards for transparency and reproducibility, with strong theoretical grounding and appropriate scope constraints.
